title: B forces - iron rod - conducting rod - spring k

content.question:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A group of students have a cylindrical iron rod with an insulated wire wrapped around it many times, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The ends of the wire can be connected to a circuit in order to produce a current in the wire, and whenever the wire has a current the iron rod behaves as a magnet.

The students wish to determine if the resulting magnetic force exerted by the end of the rod is proportional to the current in the wire. They have the following materials available.

A variable power supply for which the output current can be adjusted

An ammeter

A voltmeter

A large amount of electrical wire that can be used to construct a circuit

A mass balance

A hanger of known mass (see Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>), which is attracted to the rod when there is current in the wire

A large supply of identical metal disks of known mass (see Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>), which are not attracted to the rod when there is current in the wire

(a) Describe an experimental procedure that would allow the students to determine if the magnetic force exerted by the end of the rod is proportional to the current in the wire. Provide enough detail so that the experiment could be replicated, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

frqParts.text:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A group of students have a cylindrical iron rod with an insulated wire wrapped around it many times, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The ends of the wire can be connected to a circuit in order to produce a current in the wire, and whenever the wire has a current the iron rod behaves as a magnet.

The students wish to determine if the resulting magnetic force exerted by the end of the rod is proportional to the current in the wire. They have the following materials available.

A variable power supply for which the output current can be adjusted

An ammeter

A voltmeter

A large amount of electrical wire that can be used to construct a circuit

A mass balance

A hanger of known mass (see Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>), which is attracted to the rod when there is current in the wire

A large supply of identical metal disks of known mass (see Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>), which are not attracted to the rod when there is current in the wire

(a) Describe an experimental procedure that would allow the students to determine if the magnetic force exerted by the end of the rod is proportional to the current in the wire. Provide enough detail so that the experiment could be replicated, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

(b) Using the data collected in the procedure you described in part (a),

describe how the students could create a graph that could be used to determine if the magnetic force is proportional to wire current, and

describe how the graph would be used to make the determination.

The following day, the students are given the setup shown in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. A conductive, but nonmagnetic, rod of length <math alttext="L equals 0.150 meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.150</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math> hangs by vertical wires from two identical, metal springs. The students’ task is to determine the spring constant <math alttext="k sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> of a single spring. They no longer have access to the mass balance that was available for the experiment in parts (a) and (b), and instead will use magnetic forces to determine the spring constant. The equivalent spring constant of two springs arranged in this fashion is <math alttext="2 k sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>.
The rod is oriented horizontally and is inside a region of uniform magnetic field <math alttext="vector B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mover><mi>B</mi><mo>→</mo></mover></math> directed into the plane of Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. The springs are connected to a circuit (not shown) that produces a current <math alttext="I" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi></math> in the springs, wires, and rod. The same circuit generates the uniform magnetic field, so that <math alttext="vector B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mover><mi>B</mi><mo>→</mo></mover></math> is dependent on the current. When there is a nonzero current, the rod is displaced downward by a distance <math alttext="delta y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>y</mi></math> from its position when there is no current. The students make measurements of <math alttext="delta y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>y</mi></math> for different values of <math alttext="I" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi></math> and <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>B</mi></math>, producing the data shown in the table.
Current <math alttext="I" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi></math> <math alttext="(in amps)" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>Magnetic Field <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>B</mi></math> <math alttext="(in teslas)" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>Vertical Displacement <math alttext="delta y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>y</mi></math> <math alttext="(in millimeters)" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>mm</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math><math alttext="0.0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.0</mn></math><math alttext="0.0000" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.0000</mn></math><math alttext="0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn></math><math alttext="2.0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2.0</mn></math><math alttext="0.0064" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.0064</mn></math><math alttext="5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5</mn></math><math alttext="4.8" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4.8</mn></math><math alttext="0.0153" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.0153</mn></math><math alttext="15" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>15</mn></math><math alttext="7.6" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>7.6</mn></math><math alttext="0.0242" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.0242</mn></math><math alttext="29" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>29</mn></math><math alttext="8.8" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>8.8</mn></math><math alttext="0.0280" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.0280</mn></math><math alttext="43" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>43</mn></math><math alttext="L equals 0.150 meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.150</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math> 
(c)

i. Indicate what quantities could be graphed to yield a straight line that could be used to calculate an experimental value for <math alttext="k sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>.

Horizontal axis:__________          Vertical axis:__________

Use the remaining columns in the table, as needed, to record any quantities indicated that are not already provided in the table. Label each column and include units.

ii. On the grid in Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>, plot the data points for the quantities indicated in part (c)(i). Clearly scale and label all axes, including units. On the same grid, draw a straight line that best represents the data.
(d) Using the line drawn in part (c)(ii), calculate an experimental value for <math alttext="k sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>.

skill.text: 1.B: Create quantitative graphs with appropriate scales and units, including plotting data.
